background_dashed.customLabel: In School-age (6-12 years old) participants, there is a very strong effect in favor of SSG on Overall ASD symptoms. Based on the analysis of the quality of the evidence produced by the 7 clinical trials exploring this effect, we have a very low confidence in the estimation of this effect.

In School-age (6-12 years old) participants, there is a very strong effect in favor of SSG on Overall ASD symptoms. Based on the analysis of the quality of the evidence produced by the 7 clinical trials exploring this effect, we have a very low confidence in the estimation of this effect.

In Adolescents (13-19 years old) participants, there is a moderate-to-strong effect in favor of SSG on Overall ASD symptoms. Based on the analysis of the quality of the evidence produced by the 5 clinical trials exploring this effect, we have a very low confidence in the estimation of this effect.

In Adults (>=20 years old) participants, there is a very strong effect in favor of SSG on Overall ASD symptoms. Based on the analysis of the quality of the evidence produced by the 3 clinical trials exploring this effect, we have a very low confidence in the estimation of this effect.

In School-age (6-12 years old) participants, there is a very strong effect in favor of SSG on Restricted/repetitive behaviors. Based on the analysis of the quality of the evidence produced by the 6 clinical trials exploring this effect, we have a very low confidence in the estimation of this effect.

In Adolescents (13-19 years old) participants, there is a very strong effect in favor of SSG on Social-communication. Based on the analysis of the quality of the evidence produced by the 9 clinical trials exploring this effect, we have a very low confidence in the estimation of this effect.

In School-age (6-12 years old) participants, there is a moderate-to-strong effect in favor of SSG on Social-communication. Based on the analysis of the quality of the evidence produced by the 5 clinical trials exploring this effect, we have a very low confidence in the estimation of this effect.

In Adults (>=20 years old) participants, there is a moderate-to-strong effect in favor of SSG on Social-communication. Based on the analysis of the quality of the evidence produced by the 3 clinical trials exploring this effect, we have a very low confidence in the estimation of this effect.

In Adolescents (13-19 years old) participants, there is a moderate-to-strong effect in favor of SSG on Disruptive behaviors. Based on the analysis of the quality of the evidence produced by the 3 clinical trials exploring this effect, we have a very low confidence in the estimation of this effect.
